qas.question: Of the huge amount of microorganisms, how many cause disease in otherwise healthy individuals?

answers.text: ability of that pathogen to damage the host

context: Among the vast varieties of microorganisms, <a0_0><b5_0>relatively few<b5_0/><a0_0/> cause disease in otherwise healthy individuals. <a1_0><b6_0>Infectious disease<b6_0/><a1_0/> results from the interplay between those few pathogens and the defenses of the hosts they infect. The appearance and severity of disease resulting from any pathogen, depends upon the <a2_0><b7_0>ability of that pathogen to damage the host<b7_0/><a2_0/> as well as the ability of the host to resist the pathogen. However a host's immune system can also <a3_0><b8_0>cause damage<b8_0/><a3_0/> to the host itself in an attempt to control the infection. Clinicians therefore classify infectious microorganisms or microbes according to the status of <a4_0><b9_0>host defenses<b9_0/><a4_0/> - either as primary pathogens or as opportunistic pathogens:
